subject: Software: Settings: add setting to Software interface
commitMessage:
Software: Settings: add setting to Software interface

Added the xyz.openbmc_project.Software.Settings interface to provide
the user with some control over the Software it manages.

Currently, it only has `WriteProtected` that indicate if the software is
writeable or not.

The settings are enforced by the service that manage the property.

Change-Id: I726c247428b4e1c8b1fe9cf66554ef272bbcd231
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 4aec8027acae734a1dbc6334d53fd66ab854b81c by Patrick Williams

Can you update the Software/README.md with some words as to how you intend to use this and how other systems incorporate this new interface?  Different pieces of the software objects are created by different daemons.  I'm not sure how this State object works when you likely have multiple drives in a system and those drives may have different WriteProtected states (for example).

Sure, I'll update Software/README.md with some context.

I have noticed that the updatable state was already represented with dbus object + association

With association from
```
/xyz/openbmc_project/software/updatable/{SoftwareId}
```
to some other software to indicate that it is updatable.

This will replace that and gather the different states in one place.

----

I am not exactly sure what the issue is with

> Different pieces of the software objects are created by different daemons

My understanding is that the daemon that wants to use the States will include in as part of the daemon where it expose the software. So the daemon exposing the software will have control access to the Drive and they can independently get the WriteProtected states (Either read from the hardware or hardcoded within the daemon).

What I was thinking about is that there is a one to one mapping between state and version (the main software interface)

```
/xyz/openbmc_project/softare/software0
|__/xyz/openbmc_project/softare/software0/state
```

----

Please let me know if my understanding is incorrect.

Actually,

I think Software.Version and Software.State can just be in the same object path. So it will be available for the Installer to get the information if needed without looking for other object paths.

---

Do we not want it for which ever service exporting the Version to also export the States?
Are these supposed to be read-only properties? These seem more like software inventory properties.

I am not exactly sure.

What do you mean by software inventory properties? Do we want to put this under Inventory/Software?

Or are you referring to redfish SoftwareInventory? but yes, this is based off that. On redfish, the WriteProtect is read-write so that's why I have it this way.

Can we had more a description ?
E.g. Redfish's 
"This property shall indicate whether the software image can be overwritten, where a value `true` shall indicate that the software cannot be altered or overwritten."

Can we have more of description here?

E.g. from Redfish

                    "longDescription": "This property shall indicate whether the Update Service can update this software.  If `true`, the Service can update this software.  If `false`, the Service cannot update this software and the software is for reporting purposes only.",

WriteProtected seems more like a property or characteristic, not necessarily a state? Just seems to me that if i were to query the state of a fw version, i'd expect it to have values of active, or invalid, staged, etc, not to describe the characteristic of the version such as if it's write protected, or redundant, etc.

Does write protected overlap with updatable? The description for updatable almost sounds like it's describing a read-only version ("for reporting purposes only") and therefore it's write protected. Maybe we don't need this one?

yeah, you are right. This should be more like property to Software instead of States. Should we move this to Software Version or maybe just rename this to Software/Property?

For write Protect and Updatable, they are related but are not exactly overlap. Since there could be software that is not Updatable at all... and WriteProtected does not matter at all.

Thinking about it more... maybe it is not needed...

What about `yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Software/Settings.interface.yaml`? It seems that this property is not just something that describes the version, but also it can be modified by the user, so maybe Settings would be appropriate in this case. I see "./xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Settings.interface.yaml" perhaps as an example, where it says those properties control the behavior of the logging interface.

@patrick: Any preference/thoughts?

I will move it to `yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Software/Settings.interface.yaml` for now to clean this up a bit.

Settings make sense for this user configurable property.

Will change is if any patrick@ has and preference on it.

You mentioned that this property would replace the updatable association "and gather the different states in one place."

Why is a replacement needed? There are other apps querying the associations interface to find out the properties of the version, such as if it's functional, updatable, etc. I'd be a bit hesitant on moving one or more associations to a different interface without a reason.

Description of the associations here:
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/architecture/code-update/code-update.md#associations

I guess I don't meant that we need to migrate it to this. Just have the option to do so.

Maybe I should just update the association doc to support WriteProtected instead of adding this property as d-bus API.

---

Thanks for the reference.

just realized that if I want to to be able to remove WriteProtected... maybe it is not best to have it represented as a dbus object. Adding/removing d-bus objects seems like a bit too much to represent a boolean value?

I wouldn't think it's too much, probably is more about how it's going to be used. Would this be a property that the user set instead of being something that it's set in the image itself?
If the user sets this value, how would it be enforced? Would the code update app prevent the update and deletion of it (or do you see something like the image would need to be remounted read-only)?

If it's a user setting, probably a property makes more sense than an association, the association seems it's something the apps determine and not the user.

I think I would want the WriteProtected to be able to set by the users to match how Redfish does it.

I am not sure how the user set values will be enforced. (Not exactly sure what you mean. Dow you mean enforced by the service?) 

For,
```
Would the code update app prevent the update and deletion of it (or do you see something like the image would need to be remounted read-only)
```

Ideally, that's what the value should indicate, but I am not sure how that can be enforced by the user. I was thinking that this property/flag is more like an indicator to let us know if that is the case and provide us with options to modify it. What happens after setting the values are all dependent on the service that exported them. 

----

Ok, yeah, property does make more sense for user setting.

Ok I see, yeah I meant enforced by the service, which you confirmed that whatever is needed to enforce this property will be done by the service that exports it.
Just for my reference, do you have in mind already a service that would implement this? Were you thinking perhaps that would be added to the phophor-bmc-code-mgmt, or you're still working on a service to implement this new property at a later time?

yeah, sounds good.

I don't have any service in mind right now. I will be using this internally first to support SSD controller software for now. With the property being controlled by the SSD itself.

Not sure how this will be used in openbmc in general. Mostly added this to support Redfish properties with the same name (WriteProtected).

I'm confused how this helps the *ItemUpdater*.  Shouldn't it be created *by* the ItemUpdater?

It isn't the software version that is potentially write-protected, but the flash location where the software version is intended to be written.  Doesn't only the ItemUpdater know this?

For example, consider the BMC with two static-layout flash banks where NOR-0 is locked with a write-protect resistor.  Both flash banks could contain version v123.  It isn't v123 that is write-protected but NOR-0.  If you upload v124, how does the *ImageManager* know that v124 is not write-protected?  Only the *ItemUpdater* can know this.

oh yeah, you are right.

The Installer provide that information and allow the user to see/update it if needed.
